questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022)

 

  1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
  2. Baby on artificial feeds
  3. Baby of working mother/single parent
  4. Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
  5. Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Among the given options, babies on artificial feeds and babies of working/single parents are considered at-risk babies.

 

 

It is important to identify children at risk and give special intensive care. This is done because these children contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants on artificial feeding or with a working/single parent are at risk and require intensive care to prevent perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: Which of following is less suggestive of an organic cause of mental illness? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Auditory Hallucination

 

Auditory hallucinations are predominantly associated with psychiatric conditions rather than organic brain disorders. While they can occur in organic conditions like severe intoxications or delirium, they are most commonly observed in mental health disorders such as schizophrenia or severe depression. In contrast, organic causes of mental illness often involve symptoms that are related directly to physical changes or damage in the brain, such as those caused by neurological diseases, injuries, or infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Old age: Old age is not specifically indicative of an organic or non-organic mental illness but increases susceptibility to both, including neurodegenerative diseases.

 

Option B. Acute onset: Acute onset can often suggest an organic cause, especially when linked to brain injury or sudden health changes impacting brain function.

 

Option C. Loss of consciousness: Loss of consciousness typically points to an organic cause, as it can indicate underlying neurological issues or systemic body failures impacting brain function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with psychiatric illnesses and are less suggestive of an organic cause of mental illness compared to symptoms like loss of consciousness or acute neurological changes.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

choices.text: Increase flow rate to 15 L/min
High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but his respiratory rate is 26/min. Room air Sp02 is 86%. He is administered oxygen through a non -rebreathing mask with a flow rate of 10 L/ min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

 

  • Mechanism of Action: HFNC can deliver warmed, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min or more), creating a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) effect, reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, and improving oxygenation.
  • Effectiveness: Studies have shown its effectiveness in treating acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in COVID-19 patients. Given that the patient's SpO2 didn't improve significantly with an NRB, transitioning to HFNC might be a logical step before considering more invasive measures like intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase flow rate to 15 L/min: The non-rebreather mask (NRB) is designed to deliver high concentrations of oxygen (up to 90%). Increasing the flow rate may slightly improve the fraction of delivered oxygen, but it may not result in significant improvement in oxygenation, especially if the cause of hypoxia isn't just a low FiO2. Therefore, merely increasing the flow rate may not be sufficient to address the patient's respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are invasive interventions, reserved for patients who are in respiratory failure and cannot maintain adequate oxygenation and/or ventilation with less invasive means. While this patient is hypoxic, jumping straight to intubation without trialing intermediate steps like HFNC might be premature, especially since the patient is alert and responsive.

 

Option D. No specific intervention necessary: Given the patient's low SpO2 and increased respiratory rate, no intervention is not an appropriate choice. The patient is in respiratory distress and requires further measures to improve his oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after consuming 8 digoxin tablets. On examination, he was found to be unstable, with a heart rate of 56 beats per minute. An ECG revealed a third-degree heart block. What is the next step in this patient's care? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digoxin Immune Fab

 

For the management of Digoxin toxicity having the features of Bradycardia and a 3rd degree heart block, we need to administer Digibind, which is an antibody against Digoxin. It is also known as Digoxin immune Fab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lidocaine: Lidocaine is used to treat Ventricular Tachycardia or Ventricular Fibrillation.

 

Option C. DC cardioversion: DC cardioversion is used for tachyarrhythmias when pharmacologic treatment fails. It is not used in bradyarrhythmias.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic used for the treatment of GTCS. It can also be used as a class Ib antiarrhythmic drug for the treatment of Digoxin induced Ventricular Tachycardia, or any polymorphic ventricular tachycardia due to QT prolongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The administration of Digoxin Immune Fab is the next step in the management of life-threatening digoxin toxicity, particularly in the presence of bradycardia and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation, you notice the different color-coded waste bins meticulously arranged by the nursing staff as per the hospital's waste management protocol. If you were to guide a new intern about the appropriate disposal of items, which item among the following would you instruct them to discard in the black bin? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Glove paper cover

 

  • The paper cover for gloves constitutes regular solid waste, which should be placed in the designated black bin.
  • All types of non-infectious general refuse, including food waste, paper waste, and mineral water bottles, ought to be deposited in the black bins.
  • Bedsheets and linens that are soiled and contaminated with blood or bodily fluids should be appropriately disposed of in the yellow bin.
  • Plastic materials that are recyclable, such as gloves and contaminated gloves, should be placed in the red bins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soiled linen bedsheet: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin for contaminated waste.

 

Option C. Gloves: Should be placed in the red bin for recyclable materials.

 

Option D. Contaminated gloves: Also go in the red bin for medical waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-infectious general refuse, such as glove paper covers, should be discarded in the black bin.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TVS

 

In this case, the initial step in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected endometriosis is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). TVS is the first-line imaging modality used to assess pelvic structures and identify abnormalities such as endometriomas or nodularity in the pouch of Douglas. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and allows for direct visualization and biopsy, it is generally reserved for cases where non-invasive methods are inconclusive or when surgical intervention is planned. TVS provides valuable initial information and helps in guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for endometriosis, it is not typically the first step. TVS is preferred initially to assess the presence of endometriosis-related changes and determine if more invasive procedures are necessary.

 

Option B. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is a more invasive surgical approach generally reserved for cases requiring larger abdominal incisions or when laparoscopy is not feasible. It is not typically used as an initial diagnostic tool for endometriosis.

 

Option C. HSG (Hysterosalpingography): HSG is used primarily to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity. While it can assess tubal factor infertility, it does not provide information specific to endometriosis or the pelvic structures affected by it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

The patient's symptoms of overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination are indicative of a manic episode. Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomania: Similar to mania but the symptoms are milder, last for at least 4 days, and don't significantly impair social or occupational functioning.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: A mood disorder characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that don't meet the full criteria for a manic or major depressive episode.

 

Option D. Schizomania: This term is not standard in psychiatric diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365

choices.text: Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for protein precipitation? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

 

Protein precipitation is typically achieved using methods like alcohol, acetone, or trichloroacetic acid, or by changing the pH to the protein's isoelectric point (pI).

 

Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heavy metals: Heavy metals are not typically used for protein precipitation. They are more commonly associated with toxicity and contamination in biological samples rather than being used as precipitants.

 

Option B. Alcohol & acetone: Alcohol and acetone are frequently used for protein precipitation. They are added to protein solutions to denature proteins, causing them to precipitate out of the solution.

 

Option D. Trichloroacetic acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is commonly used for protein precipitation. It is an acidic compound that can effectively precipitate proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out. At acidic pH, protein has positive charge.  At alkaline pH, protein has negative charge. 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 19

choices.text: Cytotoxic T cells
B cells
NK cells
Helper cells

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

 

Cytotoxic T cells: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, typically derived from intracellular proteins, to cytotoxic T cells (also known as CD8+ T cells). When a cytotoxic T cell recognizes an antigen presented by MHC class I on the surface of a cell, it is activated to destroy the infected or malignant cell.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. B cells: B cells are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and by direct interaction with helper T cells (CD4+ T cells), not by MHC class I.

 

Option C. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not rely on MHC class I molecules for activation. In fact, they often target cells with low or absent MHC class I expression, which is a common strategy of infected or transformed cells to evade cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D. Helper cells: Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on APCs, not by MHC class I.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: A young child presented with nocturnal chest pain and a history of syncope has the ECG shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

  

The ECG provided shows the characteristic pattern of Brugada syndrome, which includes:

 

  1. Pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern in leads V1 and V2.
  2. ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1-V2).
  3. Coving of the ST segment.
  4. T-wave inversion following the ST-segment elevation.

 

Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, often occurring at rest or during sleep. It is more prevalent in young males and can present with symptoms such as nocturnal chest pain, syncope, or sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: Typically presents with ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads but does not usually show the pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy): Characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and possible left atrial enlargement, often presenting with deep Q waves and signs of left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG, not the specific pattern seen here.

 

Option D. DCM (Dilated Cardiomyopathy): Shows global left ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, which can lead to low voltage QRS complexes, left bundle branch block, or non-specific ST-T changes but not the specific Brugada pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brugada syndrome should be suspected in patients, especially young males, with a history of syncope or nocturnal chest pain presenting with the characteristic ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2.

questions.text: Which agency offers seeds and manure as part of applied nutrition programs in schools? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) UNICEF

 

UNICEF

 

Applied Nutrition Program

 

  • UNICEF promoted the scheme by supplying basic equipment for production and training while FAO and WHO were involved in providing technical advice
  • UNICEF provided seeds, manure and water supply equipment for developing School gardens, to be utilized in school feeding programs

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CARE:  - ‘Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere’ supports following project:

 

  • Integrated Nutrition and Health Project
  • Better Health and Nutrition Project
  • Anaemia Control Project
  • Improving Women's Health Project
  • Improved Health Care for Adolescent Girl's Project
  • Child Survival Project
  • Improving Women's Reproductive Health and Family Spacing Project
  • Konkan Integrate Development Project

 

Option B. UNDP:  The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Option D. WHO:  World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

UNICEF provides seeds, manure, and water supply equipment as part of its Applied Nutrition Program to develop school gardens, which are used in school feeding programs to improve children's nutrition.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legionella

 

BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g, polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium

 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol-bromothymol blue) agar, which includes Polymyxin, pyruvate, egg yolk, mannitol, and bromothymol blue to differentiate it from other organisms.

 

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on selective media such as Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

 

Educational Objective

 

BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with confusion, constipation, and persistent low mood. ALP was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with confusion, constipation, along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed soft tissue images, it is not the preferred imaging modality for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option B. FDG PET: PET scans are used in cancer imaging and are not specific for identifying parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. CT: While CT scans can identify anatomical details and some tumors, they lack the specificity of Sestamibi scans in identifying hyperactive parathyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Sestamibi scan is specifically useful for identifying parathyroid adenomas in patients suspected of having primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its ability to effectively localize hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

questions.text: Xanthurenic Acid in urine indicates: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

Xanthurenic assay a.k.a. Tryptophan load test. Xanthurenic acid in urine indicates Vitamin B6 deficiency. Xanthurenic acid is a metabolite that is formed during the breakdown of the amino acid tryptophan. Under normal conditions, tryptophan is metabolized along the kynurenine pathway, which involves the conversion of tryptophan to various intermediate compounds. One of these intermediates is xanthurenic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase activity, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) effect, and blood thiamine levels.

 

Option C. Niacin deficiency: Measurement of urinary N-methylnicotinamide (NMN) excretion, and niacin load test.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with a deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3) is impaired. As a result, tryptophan is metabolized through an alternative pathway, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Therefore, the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine is indicative of a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in the above finding? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zona Occludens

 

  • The structure that is most likely damaged to result in severe watery diarrhea resembling rice gruel stool is the Zona Occludens.
  • Zona Occludens, also known as Tight Junctions, are specialized intercellular junctions between epithelial cells that regulate the movement of substances across the intestinal wall. They are located at the apical end of the lateral membrane of adjacent epithelial cells and are responsible for maintaining the integrity and impermeability of the intestinal barrier.
  • Damage to the Zona Occludens can result in increased permeability of the intestinal barrier, leading to the leakage of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is often seen in infectious diarrhea caused by bacterial or viral pathogens that can damage the tight junctions, leading to increased intestinal permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gap Junction: Incorrect. Gap junctions are involved in cell-cell communication and the passage of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells, but they are not directly involved in regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option C. Adherent Junction: Incorrect. Adherent junctions are involved in maintaining cell-cell adhesion but are not primarily responsible for regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Incorrect. Hemidesmosomes are involved in cell-matrix adhesion and do not play a role in the regulation of intestinal permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions) can result in increased intestinal permeability, leading to severe watery diarrhea. These tight junctions are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is not a part of immediate management in the next 24 hours? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antiparasitic drugs

 

Explanation:

 

Antiparasitic drugs, such as albendazole or praziquantel, are not part of the immediate management. Starting antiparasitic treatment without adequate anti-inflammatory coverage (steroids) can worsen the patient's condition by increasing inflammation due to the destruction of the cysts.

 

Antiparasitic therapy (albendazole or praziquantel or both) can be initiated later, typically along with steroids, to mitigate this risk.

 

Doses –

 

  • Albendazole – 15 mg/Kg/day (Max. of 1200 mg/day)
  • Praziquantel – 50-100 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses

 

Note – Severe disease or >2 cyst – Combination of both drug in doses of 15 mg/kg/day Albendazole + 50mg/kg/day Praziquantel

 

Other Options:

 

In a case of neurocysticercosis, the immediate management of a patient presenting with seizures and multiple parenchymal cysts on CT includes:

 

Option B. Steroids: To reduce inflammation and surrounding edema caused by the cysts.

 

Option C. Antiepileptics: To control seizures, which are the most common presentation of neurocysticercosis.

 

Option D. Anti-edema treatment: To manage any cerebral edema and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the immediate management of neurocysticercosis presenting with seizures, antiepileptics, steroids, and anti-edema treatment are essential, while antiparasitic drugs can be started later.

questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

The structure marked in the image is the fibula's neck.

 

The common peroneal nerve supplies motor fibers to the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, including the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles, which evert the foot and plantarflex the ankle joint. It also provides sensory fibers to the skin over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.

 

Injuries to the common peroneal nerve can occur due to trauma or compression, and can result in weakness or paralysis of the muscles it innervates, as well as sensory loss over the affected area. Common peroneal nerve injuries can be treated with conservative measures such as physiotherapy or surgery in severe cases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is a sensory nerve in the calf region. It is formed by branches from both the common peroneal and tibial nerves. The sural nerve provides sensation to the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot. It runs more distally in the leg and is not closely associated with the neck of the fibula.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve is another major branch of the sciatic nerve. After the division of the sciatic nerve, the tibial nerve continues its course in the posterior compartment of the leg, supplying muscles there and then continuing into the foot. It is primarily responsible for plantar flexion of the foot and toe flexion. The tibial nerve does not have a close relation with the neck of the fibula as it runs more medially in the leg.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh. It is responsible for hip flexion and knee extension. This nerve is located in the anterior aspect of the thigh, far away from the neck of the fibula, and has no direct relation with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Common peroneal nerve (also known as common fibular nerve), a significant branch of the sciatic nerve, follows a course along the thigh's posterior compartment and wraps around the fibula's neck, making it susceptible to injury. After encircling the fibula, it splits into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves, which innervate the leg's lateral and anterior compartments and contribute sensory functions to parts of the foot.

questions.text: A young male, diagnosed with thalassemia, is experiencing iron overload due to repeated blood transfusions over the years. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate for managing his chronic iron overload? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deferiprone

 

Deferiprone is an appropriate medication for managing chronic iron overload in a patient with thalassemia who has undergone multiple blood transfusions. As an oral iron chelator, deferiprone is effective in reducing excess iron levels in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDTA: This chelating agent is primarily used for lead poisoning, not for iron overload.

 

Option B. Desferrioxamine: Although desferrioxamine is a chelating agent used for iron overload, it's typically administered via injection, which may be less convenient than oral deferiprone.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: This is primarily used for Wilson's disease and certain rheumatoid conditions, not typically for iron chelation in thalassemia patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deferiprone is an effective oral iron chelator used to manage chronic iron overload in thalassemia patients, making it a convenient and appropriate choice for reducing excess iron levels resulting from repeated blood transfusions.

questions.text: A woman suffered from sunburn after enjoying a vacation on a beach. Now while taking a shower lukewarm water (40 degree celsiuis) touches her back causing her to feel pain. What type of receptors are activated by lukewarm water and what causes her to feel pain? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Innocuous thermal receptor - allodynia

 

After a sunburn, the skin becomes sensitive. When the patient takes a bath with 40-degree Celsius water, which is lukewarm and not hot, the warm sensation should not normally cause pain. This temperature is considered a non-painful, or innocuous, thermal stimulus. In this scenario, the innocuous thermal receptors, which usually respond to non-painful stimuli, are activated. However, due to the skin's heightened sensitivity after sunburn, this harmless stimulus results in a painful sensation. This phenomenon, where a normally non-painful stimulus causes pain, is known as allodynia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noxious thermal receptor - hyperalgesia: This would occur if a painful stimulus led to an exaggerated pain response. However, in this case, the stimulus (40-degree water) is not painful and hence does not activate noxious receptors.

 

Option C. Noxious thermal receptor - allodynia: Allodynia refers to pain resulting from a non-painful stimulus, but noxious receptors respond to painful stimuli. Therefore, this option is incorrect because it misidentifies the type of receptor involved.

 

Option D. Innocuous thermal receptor - hyperalgesia: Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated pain response to a painful stimulus. Since 40-degree water is not a painful stimulus, hyperalgesia is not applicable here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allodynia is a condition where a normally non-painful stimulus, such as lukewarm water, causes pain. This occurs due to the activation of innocuous thermal receptors in the setting of heightened skin sensitivity, such as after a sunburn.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the following image. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II

 

  • The Salter-Harris classification system is used to describe fractures involving the growth plate (physis) in children. 
  • The types range from I to V, with increasing severity:
    • Type I: Slip or separation of the growth plate.
    • Type II: Fracture that involves a part of the metaphysis and the growth plate. This is the most common type and is also known as the Thurston-Holland sign.
    • Type III: Fracture through the growth plate and epiphysis, involving the joint surface, causing epiphyseal split.
    • Type IV: Fracture through the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.
    • Type V: Compression/crush injury to the growth plate with initially normal x-ray.

 

 

  • In the provided image, the fracture depicted involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis, which classifies it as a Type II injury.
  • Remember: 
    • MC type is Type II.
    • Location of Epiphyseal Injuries: When it comes to epiphyseal injuries, particularly in pediatric cases, these injuries typically occur through the zone of hypertrophy of the growth plate. This zone is one of the layers of the growth plate where chondrocytes mature and enlarge before the end of the bone lengthens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Type I: Involves only the growth plate without extending into the metaphysis or epiphysis.

 

Option Type III: Involves the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint.

 

Option Type IV: Involves the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Type II Salter-Harris physeal injury in children.
  • A Type II Salter-Harris fracture involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis and is the most common type of growth plate fracture.

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syphilis

 

Given scenario points out to a diagnosis of syphilis

 

ACQUIRED SYPHILIS:

 

Mode of acquisition - Sexual transmission & Blood transfusion

 

Stages are as follows –

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: In this condition both genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy are painful. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, with an incubation period of 2-5 days.

 

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: It causes painful ulcers in the genital region and localized tender lymphadenopathy, caused by HSV 2 > 1.

 

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale (aka donovanosis): It is caused by the bacterium Calymmatobacter / Klebsiella granulomatis. There is NO pain in Ulcer & NO Lymphadenopathy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis (syphiLESS) is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a Painless genital ulcer and Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are classic presentations of this sexually transmitted infection.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no: 28.8-29, 29.13-16

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 339, 341, 342

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 379-383

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

 

True. Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture, which means that it gets absorbed by the body over time. The process involves enzymatic degradation (breaking down by enzymes) and phagocytosis by macrophages (special cells that engulf and digest foreign substances, microbes, and cellular debris).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is made from cat gut: While the term "catgut" might suggest that the material is derived from cats, this is a misnomer. Catgut suture material is historically derived from the submucosal layer of sheep or goat intestines. The term is a shortened version of the word "cattlegut."

 

Option B. It is made from rabbit gut: This statement is also misleading. As mentioned, the primary sources for catgut are sheep and goat intestines, not rabbit.

 

Option D. It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: This statement is inaccurate in the context of chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is treated with chromium salts, not nickel salts. Chromium salts are used to cross-link the collagen fibers in the catgut, which increases its resistance to degradation, thus prolonging its time before being absorbed in the tissue. This treatment also improves the suture's handling properties.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material derived from sheep or goat intestines and is absorbed in the body through enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

 

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used.

 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black.

 

Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and Option B. Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

 

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

 

 

Option C. Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor.

 

Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

 

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, the presence of dichotomous branching at acute angles in histopathological examination should prompt consideration of Aspergillus infection, necessitating prompt antifungal therapy to manage the potential for invasive disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis. The symptoms started 3 hours ago. On examination, BP is 200/100 mm Hg. CT head is shown below. Which of the following should not be done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate thrombolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis, and the CT scan shows evidence of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), indicating a hemorrhagic stroke. In the case of hemorrhagic stroke, immediate thrombolysis is contraindicated as it can worsen the bleeding. Thrombolytic agents, such as tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), are used to dissolve clots in ischemic strokes but can be harmful in hemorrhagic strokes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood pressure control: Managing high blood pressure is crucial in patients with hemorrhagic stroke to prevent further bleeding.

 

Option C. Clotting factor administration: In cases of hemorrhagic stroke, administering clotting factors or other agents to help control bleeding may be necessary.

 

Option D. Edema management: Managing cerebral edema is essential to reduce intracranial pressure and prevent further complications in hemorrhagic stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate thrombolysis should never be administered in patients with hemorrhagic stroke, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient's condition.

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically stored in the lowest compartment of the ILR? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV

 

In an Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR), vaccines are stored at specific temperatures to maintain their potency. The lowest compartment of the ILR is the coldest part, which is optimal for storing vaccines that require the coldest temperatures. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is stored in the lowest compartment because it requires the coldest storage conditions to remain effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penta: Pentavalent vaccine (which protects against five diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b) does not require the lowest temperature and is generally stored in the middle compartments.

 

Option B. DPT: The DPT vaccine (Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus) does not need to be stored in the coldest compartment and is kept in the upper or middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Option C. Hep B: The Hepatitis B vaccine also does not require the lowest storage temperature and is kept in the middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) should be stored in the lowest compartment of the Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR) due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions.

choices.text: Addison's disease

questions.text: These findings are suggestive of which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acromegaly

 

Explanation:  

 

The images provided show a patient with coarse facial features, prognathism (protruding jaw), frontal bossing (prominent forehead), and prominent jaw bones. These are characteristic features of acromegaly, a condition caused by excessive growth hormone (GH) production, usually due to a pituitary adenoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Addison's disease: Characterized by hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and weight loss, not by coarse facial features.

 

Option B. Gigantism: Also caused by excess GH, but it occurs before the closure of the growth plates in children and adolescents, leading to increased height and growth of long bones. The facial features are not as prominent as in acromegaly.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Characterized by features such as central obesity, moon face, buffalo hump, and purple striae, not by coarse facial features and prognathism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acromegaly is diagnosed based on characteristic facial features such as coarse facial features, prognathism, and frontal bossing, resulting from excessive growth hormone production.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, the land area necessary to implement the controlled tipping using the trench method is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1 acre

 

Controlled tipping or controlled burial is similar in principle to sanitary landfill but at a smaller scale that is appropriate in rural areas. 

 

Trench Method— The waste collection truck deposits its load into the trench where the bulldozer spreads and compacts it. Approximately, 1 acre of land is required for a population of 10000 for a depth of 2 feet and usable for 1-year duration

 

Educational Objective:

 

For implementing controlled tipping using the trench method, 1 acre of land is sufficient for a population of 10,000, considering a depth of 2 feet and a usage duration of one year.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with low-grade fever and cough. Chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Miliary TB

 

The patient in this case presents with a low-grade fever and cough. The chest X-ray reveals multiple small nodules distributed throughout the bilateral lung fields, which is characteristic of miliary tuberculosis (TB). Miliary TB is a form of tuberculosis that occurs when a large number of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria spread through the bloodstream to multiple organs, including the lungs. This results in the appearance of numerous tiny nodules on the chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung Cancer: While metastatic lung cancer can sometimes present with a similar pattern of multiple nodules on a chest X-ray, the presence of low-grade fever and the specific distribution of nodules are more indicative of miliary TB, especially in regions with a high prevalence of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that typically form in pre-existing lung cavities, often resulting from previous tuberculosis infections. The chest X-ray appearance of aspergillomas is quite different from the diffuse nodules seen in miliary TB.

 

Option D. ARDS: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) presents with diffuse alveolar damage and is characterized by rapid onset of widespread inflammation in the lungs. The chest X-ray findings for ARDS usually show diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than the small, discrete nodules seen in miliary TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary tuberculosis should be suspected in patients with low-grade fever, cough, and a chest X-ray showing multiple small nodules throughout the lung fields, especially in regions with high tuberculosis prevalence.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the OPD with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. On workup, it reveals normocytic normochromic anemia with hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis was done that shows M Spike in gamma region. Which of the following should be used to confirm the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bence Jones proteins in urine

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest that the patient may be suffering from multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a type of blood cancer that arises from plasma cells in the bone marrow. The characteristic features of multiple myeloma include:

 

  1. Lower back pain: Often related to lytic bone lesions caused by the disease.
  2. Normocytic normochromic anemia: A common finding due to the infiltration of bone marrow by malignant plasma cells.
  3. Hypercalcemia: Occurs due to increased bone resorption from lytic bone lesions.
  4. M Spike on serum protein electrophoresis: Represents a monoclonal protein or paraprotein, a hallmark of multiple myeloma.

 

To confirm the diagnosis, the detection of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is crucial. Bence Jones proteins are free light chains of immunoglobulins that are produced in excess by malignant plasma cells and can be detected in the urine of multiple myeloma patients. The presence of these proteins supports the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

 

Definitive diagnosis: Bone marrow biopsy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver function test: While it can be altered in various conditions, it is not specific or useful for diagnosing multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. UACR (urine albumin-creatinine ratio) test: This test is typically used to assess kidney function (stage & progression of disease), particularly in conditions like chronic kidney disease, and does not specifically confirm multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Heat and acetic acid test: This is a basic test for proteinuria but does not specifically detect Bence Jones proteins or confirm multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is a key diagnostic test for confirming multiple myeloma, especially when the clinical presentation includes back pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and an M spike on serum protein electrophoresis.

choices.text: Palm and soles

questions.text: Where are the apocrine glands present among the given options? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axilla

 

Option C Axilla:

 

  • Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axillae, areola and groin.
  • They are sweat glands that become active at puberty and are responsible for the body odor associated with sweating because they produce a thicker, milky sweat that, once degraded by skin bacteria, generates a noticeable odor.

 

 

  • These glands are most numerous in the axillary region, which is why the axilla is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palm and Soles:

 

  • The skin of palms and soles is primarily populated with eccrine sweat glands, not apocrine.
  • Eccrine glands are involved in thermoregulation and are not associated with hair follicles. They produce a watery sweat that is not typically odorous.

 

Option B. Face:

 

  • While there are some apocrine glands on the face, they are not as numerous or as active as those in the axilla.
  • The face primarily contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands.

 

Option D. Scalp:

 

  • The scalp does have apocrine glands, but they are far less concentrated and active compared to those in the axilla.
  • The scalp also contains eccrine sweat glands and is rich in sebaceous glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify the axilla as the primary location of apocrine sweat glands.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 2.8

choices.text: Anterior transmural
Posterior transmural

questions.text: Which of the following myocardial infarcts cause aneurysm as a post-MI complication? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior transmural

 

As a post-MI complication, anterior transmural infarcts contribute to aneurysm formation.

 

Myocardial infarction (MI) complications such left ventricular aneurysms (LVAs) and pseudoaneurysms can cause mortality or severe morbidity. The most frequent outcome of MI is an LVA, which typically involves the anterior wall.

 

Conduction blockages, right ventricular involvement, or both are more likely to make posterior transmural infarcts problematic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendocardial: These infarcts affect only the innermost layers of the heart wall and do not typically cause aneurysms.

 

Option C. Posterior transmural: While serious and affecting the full thickness of the heart wall, posterior infarcts are less likely than anterior infarcts to result in aneurysm formation due to the smaller area typically involved and differing hemodynamic forces.

 

Option D. Inferior wall: Inferior MIs can lead to complications like arrhythmias or heart block but are less commonly associated with aneurysm formation compared to anterior transmural MIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior transmural myocardial infarctions are most commonly associated with the formation of left ventricular aneurysms due to the location, extent of myocardial damage, and the dynamics of ventricular pressure that exacerbate the risk of wall outpouching and aneurysm development in this region.
